ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Absolutely. No class in Islamic History at Yale can hold a candle to Professor Bowering's course.

A traditional history course. A ton of memorization, and it would be a lot better if it were actually a lecture course rather than one masquerading as a seminar. It was a bit scattered this year, but you'll no doubt learn a ton, and have access to a top notch professor in the field.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The course was an excellent overview of Islamic history up to 1500. It provides the general historical framework for his long and vast field.

I didn't have much of a knowledge of the history of the Islamic Empire-- I had taken Islamic Theology but this covered transitions in thought, not action. So it was helpful (albiet painful-- I'm not really one for strict memorization).
